title: Investigating Forecasting Models for Pandemic Infections Using Heterogeneous Data Sources: A 2-year Study with COVID-19
summary: This paper presents a two-year case study on COVID-19 forecasting in Cyprus, utilizing a heterogeneous dataset comprising epidemiological data, vaccination records, policy measures, and weather conditions. The research aims to improve pandemic preparedness and response strategies by analyzing infection trends, assessing forecasting model performance, and examining the influence of external factors on disease dynamics.

title: The nexus between disease surveillance, adaptive human behavior and epidemic containment
summary: This paper investigates the complex interplay between disease surveillance, information dissemination, adaptive human behavior, and centralized public health interventions in epidemic containment. It reveals that robust surveillance, while triggering early population responses, can paradoxically lead to larger epidemic sizes, with optimal containment achieved by balancing risk information and disease transmission, mediated by surveillance. The study emphasizes the critical role of these feedback loops in designing effective control policies.

title: Including frameworks of public health ethics in computational modelling of infectious disease interventions
summary: This paper introduces a proof-of-concept method to integrate public health ethical frameworks directly into the evaluation of computational models for infectious disease interventions. By examining trade-offs between values like outcome equity and aggregate benefit in a vaccination model, it demonstrates how optimal strategies vary depending on the ethical priorities, offering a more ethically nuanced approach to public health decision-making.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Infectious Disease Prediction and Prevention: A Comprehensive Review
summary: This comprehensive review analyzes the advancements of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), and Deep Learning (DL) in infectious disease prediction and prevention. It highlights significant challenges concerning the types of data utilized and the appropriate learning methods applied, categorizing existing research into three distinct areas based on data source and prediction objective. The paper critically assesses AI's potential and outlines its limitations in the context of infectious disease management.

title: Infectious Disease Forecasting in India using LLM's and Deep Learning
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach combining Deep Learning algorithms and Large Language Models (LLMs) for forecasting the severity of infectious disease outbreaks in India. By utilizing historical disease and climatic data, the research aims to establish a robust predictive system to enable early detection and intervention. This initiative seeks to significantly reduce the impact of outbreaks on public health and enhance the resilience of healthcare systems against future epidemics.

title: Disease Outbreak Detection and Forecasting: A Review of Methods and Data Sources
summary: This paper provides a comprehensive review of existing standard methods for disease outbreak detection and forecasting using time series data. It examines how these methods utilize both conventional public health surveillance data and novel digital sources such as social media and internet search trends, specifically focusing on literature published between 2015 and 2022.

title: Bayesian estimation of transmission networks for infectious diseases
summary: This paper introduces a novel Bayesian framework that integrates genomic and temporal data to reconstruct complex transmission networks for infectious diseases. The model enhances accuracy by accounting for latent periods, differentiating between symptom onset and actual infection time, and allowing for multiple pathogen lineages, which more accurately reflects real-world transmission dynamics. Through simulations, the model demonstrated reliable estimation of both network parameters and the transmission network itself, with effective identification of direct transmission events via hypothesis testing.

title: Rebound in epidemic control: How misaligned vaccination timing amplifies infection peaks
summary: In this study, we explore the dynamic interplay between the timing of vaccination campaigns and the trajectory of disease spread in a population. Through comprehensive data analysis and modeling, we have uncovered a counter-intuitive phenomenon: initiating a vaccination process at an inopportune mom...

title: An early warning indicator trained on stochastic disease-spreading models with different noises
summary: This paper introduces a novel deep learning-based early warning indicator (EWS) for infectious disease outbreaks, specifically designed to function robustly amidst diverse real-world noise sources like additive white, multiplicative environmental, and demographic noise. By training on stochastic disease-spreading models incorporating these noise types, the indicator demonstrates superior performance in capturing impending outbreak transitions compared to existing methods, as validated on real-world COVID-19 data and simulated time series.

title: Wastewater-based Epidemiology for COVID-19 Surveillance and Beyond: A Survey
summary: This paper provides a comprehensive survey of Wastewater-based Epidemiology (WBE) for COVID-19 surveillance, highlighting its potential to complement traditional clinical testing due to limitations in coverage and consistency. It systematically reviews current advances in wastewater sampling, sample testing, and data analytical methods for tracking SARS-CoV-2 prevalence within communities. The survey concludes by outlining open challenges and encouraging future research to advance WBE for broader infectious disease surveillance.

title: Possible counter-intuitive impact of local vaccine mandates for vaccine-preventable infectious diseases
summary: This paper models the impact of local school-level vaccine mandates on the spread of vaccine-preventable diseases using a stochastic SIR household model. It reveals a counter-intuitive finding: if overall population vaccine coverage is near herd immunity, such mandates may paradoxically *increase* both the probability of an outbreak and the infection risk for medically exempt individuals, primarily due to the clustering of unvaccinated children in non-mandate schools.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Vaccine Hesitancy on the Allocation of Vital Resources During COVID-19 Pandemic
summary: This paper introduces an enhanced SEIR epidemiological model for COVID-19, integrating the dynamics of vaccine hesitancy (VH) and healthcare resource availability, which were previously overlooked. Through simulations based on public VH data, the study demonstrates that reducing VH, ensuring adequate critical healthcare resources, and implementing timely vaccination programs are paramount for improving health outcomes and minimizing fatalities during a pandemic.

title: Large-scale Long-tailed Disease Diagnosis on Radiology Images
summary: This paper introduces RadDiag, a foundational transformer-based model for comprehensive 2D and 3D radiology image diagnosis across various modalities and anatomies. It leverages a novel large-scale, clinician-reviewed dataset, RP3D-DiagDS, compiled from publicly available online medical images to overcome data scarcity and privacy issues. RadDiag demonstrates high diagnostic accuracy (95.14% AUC internally) and state-of-the-art zero-shot or fine-tuned performance on external hospital datasets, showcasing the immense value of online medical data for developing generalist AI in healthcare.

title: The Effect of Vaccination on the Competitive Advantage of Two Strains of an Infectious Disease
summary: This paper investigates how natural and vaccine-induced immunity influence the competitive dynamics between two strains of an infectious disease with contrasting epidemiological traits (one more transmissible, the other more immune-resistant). It demonstrates that vaccination critically alters strain dominance, capable of causing dramatic shifts between prevalent strains, with the specific outcome depending on the integration of natural and vaccine immunity mechanisms.

title: Infectious disease surveillance needs for the United States: lessons from COVID-19
summary: This paper outlines the critical needs for upgrading infectious disease surveillance, forecasting, and modeling systems in the United States, leveraging lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic. It defines the necessary data elements and system requirements to support evidence-based public health decision-making across various levels of authority, while also addressing health equity.

title: Integrative AI-Driven Strategies for Advancing Precision Medicine in Infectious Diseases and Beyond: A Novel Multidisciplinary Approach
summary: This paper introduces a novel multidisciplinary approach leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to advance precision medicine, specifically targeting infectious diseases and other complex conditions. It proposes integrating diverse patient data, including multi-omics (genomics, proteomics, microbiomics) and clinical profiles, to enable AI-driven insights for precise diagnosis, personalized treatment, and proactive patient-centric healthcare.

title: The Challenges and Opportunities in Creating an Early Warning System for Global Pandemics
summary: This paper addresses the critical need for a global early warning system (EWS) for pandemics, arguing that despite the predictability of pandemic factors, essential infectious disease monitoring programs are being dismantled. It proposes a comprehensive EWS integrating diverse data streams (genomics, climate, social dynamics, healthcare infrastructure) powered by community-driven modeling and democratized AI to build resilient global health and economic systems. The authors demonstrate the potential through an example focused on dengue fever in Brazil, highlighting how thoughtfully designed technology platforms can enable precision disease detection and response.

title: Modeling COVID-19 Transmission using IDSIM, an Epidemiological-Modelling Desktop App with Multi-Level Immunization Capabilities
summary: This paper introduces IDSIM, a native Windows desktop application developed for local public health units in Ontario, Canada, to provide in-house epidemiological modeling capabilities for infectious diseases like COVID-19. It implements a multi-stratified compartmental model capable of simulating various public health measures, virus variants, and vaccination levels. The study presents simulation results investigating factors influencing COVID-19 transmission in Durham Region, providing insights into the roles of natural and vaccine-induced immunity, and predicting the impact of the Omicron variant.

title: Sensitivity analysis in an Immuno-Epidemiological Vector-Host Model
summary: This paper introduces a novel approach to Sensitivity Analysis (SA) by integrating within-host virus-immune system interactions with population-level epidemic models. It utilizes an age-since-infection structured vector-host model where epidemiological parameters are functions of within-host dynamics, demonstrating that immunological parameters significantly impact population-scale disease metrics like R0 and infectiousness, with a case study on Rift Valley Fever Disease.

title: Modelling the Effect of Vaccination and Human Behaviour on the Spread of Epidemic Diseases on Temporal Networks
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model on time-varying networks to analyze the spread of recurrent epidemic diseases in partially vaccinated populations, considering various realistic factors like differential vaccine effectiveness, testing, NPIs, and human behavior. It analytically derives the epidemic threshold and endemic prevalence, revealing that while vaccination mitigates severe illness, it can paradoxically contribute to resurgent outbreaks in certain scenarios, necessitating enhanced testing, public caution, or NPI reintroduction for complete eradication.

title: Unlocking capacities of viral genomics for the COVID-19 pandemic response
summary: This paper discusses the immense opportunities presented by viral genomics and high-throughput sequencing for understanding and responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. It highlights how the vast amounts of SARS-CoV-2 genomic data, coupled with bioinformatics, are critical for tracking variant spread, reconstructing epidemic dynamics, and informing public health surveillance and interventions.

title: Modeling the COVID-19 pandemic: A primer and overview of mathematical epidemiology
summary: This paper offers a comprehensive review and primer on the mathematical epidemiology models applied during the COVID-19 pandemic. It critically examines the foundational Kermack-McKendrick type models and their advanced extensions, detailing how these frameworks have been employed to understand complex disease dynamics, assess intervention efficacy, and predict epidemiological outcomes. The authors highlight the intrinsic properties, key findings, and inherent deficiencies associated with these diverse modeling approaches.

title: Population-scale testing can suppress the spread of infectious disease
summary: This paper proposes a robust intervention for infectious disease control based on repeated, population-scale testing and isolation of infected individuals. Through rigorous analysis and simulations, the authors demonstrate that a sufficient testing rate can reduce the effective reproduction number (R_e) below 1.0, leading to rapid epidemic collapse, independent of strong assumptions about test accuracy or compliance. This strategy offers a rapid response to emerging pathogens, complementing traditional pharmaceutical interventions.

title: Controlling infectious diseases: the decisive phase effect on a seasonal vaccination strategy
summary: This paper investigates the chaotic dynamics often observed in seasonally forced Susceptible-Infected-Recovered (SIR) epidemic models, which poses challenges for public health predictability. It proposes and demonstrates that a phase control technique, interpreted as a weak perturbation on a seasonal vaccination strategy, can effectively suppress these chaotic oscillations. The study finds that the phase difference between the seasonal contact rate and the seasonal vaccination effort is a decisive factor in converting unpredictable disease dynamics into regular, manageable patterns.

title: Optimal vaccination program for two infectious diseases with cross immunity
summary: This paper develops a two-layer Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR) model to identify optimal vaccination programs for two infectious diseases with cross-immunity, aiming to prevent outbreaks at minimum cost. It identifies three distinct scenarios for optimal vaccination and provides an analytical criterion based on vaccine costs to specify the best program.

title: Antibiotic treatment, duration of infectiousness, and disease transmission
summary: This paper investigates the counterintuitive possibility that antibiotic treatment, while curing individuals, could paradoxically increase disease transmission by prolonging the duration of infectiousness. It proposes that if within-host pathogen density influences both recovery (via treatment) and other removal events (like isolation or mortality), antibiotics might relax the overall removal rate, thereby extending the period an individual is capable of spreading the disease. The study uses a deterministic within-host model coupled with between-host dynamics to identify conditions under which antibiotic therapy can lead to an increased expected number of new infections.

title: IoT Platform for COVID-19 Prevention and Control: A Survey
summary: This survey paper proposes a novel fog-cloud combined Internet of Things (IoT) platform designed for the systematic and intelligent prevention and control of COVID-19, as well as future infectious disease epidemics. It synthesizes state-of-the-art literature to demonstrate how IoT's ubiquitous sensing and connectivity can enable five critical non-pharmaceutical interventions, including symptom diagnosis, quarantine monitoring, contact tracing, outbreak forecasting, and SARS-CoV-2 mutation tracking.

title: Medical Imaging and Computational Image Analysis in COVID-19 Diagnosis: A Review
summary: This review paper synthesizes studies on automated medical image analysis for COVID-19 diagnosis, focusing on characteristic imaging signs and the performance of AI-based approaches. It highlights that medical imaging can detect COVID-19 early, even in asymptomatic patients, and that automated machine learning methods offer high accuracy, reduced diagnostic time, cost, and error.

title: Dynamics of epidemic diseases without guaranteed immunity
summary: This paper introduces a novel mathematical model for epidemic spread that challenges conventional immunity assumptions, proposing that recovered individuals only gain immunity if continuously infected for a period, otherwise reverting to susceptibility. Utilizing field theory, the model identifies distinct 'pandemic' and 'response' phases and accurately describes the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak in Wuhan, suggesting only 30% of recovered agents developed immunity.

title: Beyond just "flattening the curve": Optimal control of epidemics with purely non-pharmaceutical interventions
summary: This paper computes an optimal non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI) strategy for epidemics when vaccines are unavailable and complete containment is impossible. Utilizing an extended SEIR model and continuous-time optimal control theory, it identifies a single-intervention scenario that simultaneously minimizes disease-related deaths, establishes sufficient natural immunity to prevent a second wave, and minimizes socio-economic costs. The resulting strategy is described as a delicate balance operating close to the system's stability boundary, necessitating constant vigilance.

title: Severity Detection Tool for Patients with Infectious Disease
summary: This paper presents a machine learning-based tool for the automatic detection of Autonomic Nervous System Dysfunction (ANSD) severity in patients suffering from serious infectious diseases like Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease (HFMD) and tetanus. By analyzing physiological data (ECG and PPG waveforms) from low-cost wearable sensors, the approach extracts novel time and frequency domain features, outperforming standard HRV analysis, and shows promising results in classifying ANSD levels. This innovation aims to facilitate early diagnosis and treatment in resource-limited settings, thereby improving patient care.

title: Coupling the circadian rhythms of population movement and the immune system in infectious disease modeling
summary: This paper introduces a novel approach to infectious disease modeling by integrating the circadian rhythms of both the human immune system and daily population movement patterns. It demonstrates that these coupled biological and behavioral cycles significantly influence epidemic risk, generally constraining disease emergence, and suggests that manipulating these temporal dynamics could be a strategy for outbreak mitigation.

title: Geographically-dependent individual-level models for infectious diseases transmission
summary: This paper introduces Geographically-Dependent Individual-Level Models (GD-ILMs), an extension of traditional Individual-Level Models (ILMs), to explicitly account for the influence of absolute spatial location and varying risk factors on infectious disease transmission. By incorporating a conditional autoregressive model, GD-ILMs can capture unobserved spatially structured latent covariates, enabling the identification of high-risk geographical regions and formulation of etiological hypotheses for disease spread. The reliability of these new models was investigated using simulated epidemic data and real-world 2009 Alberta seasonal influenza outbreak data.

title: A Data-Validated Host-Parasite Model for Infectious Disease Outbreaks
summary: This paper develops and validates a mathematical host-parasite model using experimental data from the guppy-Gyrodactylus turnbulli system to understand infectious disease dynamics. The model estimates the basic reproduction number (R_0) and identifies parasite growth rate and host immune response as critical factors influencing outbreak peak and timing. These findings underscore the importance of host resistance and parasite virulence in disease control strategies.

title: Early Detection of Influenza outbreaks in the United States
summary: This paper presents a multivariate algorithm that utilizes freely available online data, specifically Google search and Wikipedia pageview time series, to provide early warning of emerging influenza epidemics in the United States. It demonstrates that this method can detect seasonal influenza outbreaks an average of 16.4 weeks and the 2009 H1N1 pandemic 5 weeks prior to traditional CDC surveillance thresholds being met, without relying on traditional health records.

title: Supervised learning improves disease outbreak detection
summary: Zacher and Czogiel introduce the first supervised learning approach for infectious disease outbreak detection using Hidden Markov Models (HMMs). This novel method leverages routinely collected public health surveillance data to improve detection accuracy. The model significantly reduces false positive rates (up to 50%) while maintaining comparable sensitivity, thereby enhancing the efficiency and reliability of outbreak detection systems.

title: The need for an integrative thinking to fight against emerging infectious diseases
summary: This paper presents the proceedings of the 5th seminar on emerging infectious diseases (EIDs), outlining seven priority proposals for an integrative approach to combat these threats. The recommendations encompass enhancing research, surveillance, local capacity building, patient care optimization, policy and healthcare provider education, governance reform, and economic considerations to effectively address EIDs. The overarching aim is to foster a more proactive and coordinated global response to new infectious disease risks.

title: Global stability of epidemic models with imperfect vaccination and quarantine on scale-free networks
summary: This paper introduces and analyzes novel epidemic models, SVIQR (with permanent immunity) and SVIQS (without permanent immunity), incorporating variable population size, degree-related imperfect vaccination, and quarantine on scale-free networks. It mathematically investigates the global stability of disease-free and endemic equilibria, revealing distinct dynamical behaviors and conditions for disease persistence under various public health interventions. The findings provide a robust framework for understanding and predicting disease spread on complex networks.

title: Early warning signals in plant disease outbreaks
summary: This paper introduces a lattice-based epidemic model coupled with a stochastic process to study plant disease spread, revealing a critical transition from local confinement to widespread outbreaks dependent on susceptible host density. It successfully demonstrates that early-warning indicators can forecast these critical shifts, offering a predictive framework applicable to broader infectious disease epidemiology.

title: Infection-acquired versus vaccine-acquired immunity in an SIRWS model
summary: This paper introduces an SIRWS epidemiological model to analyze the re-emergence of pertussis, focusing on the interplay between infection-acquired and vaccine-acquired immunity durations. It reveals that differences in these immunity durations profoundly influence long-term disease patterns, with vaccination potentially inducing cyclic behavior and increased vaccine coverage paradoxically leading to increased overall transmission despite reducing primary infections, alongside longer, taller epidemic cycles.

title: On the predictability of infectious disease outbreaks
summary: This paper investigates the fundamental information-theoretic limits to forecasting infectious disease outbreaks using permutation entropy as a model-independent measure. It identifies a fundamental entropy barrier for time series forecasting, which, for most diseases, lies beyond the timescale of single outbreaks, implying substantial predictability within actionable timeframes. The research advocates for transitioning from time series to dynamic modeling approaches to improve forecasting accuracy and address variations in predictability driven by model structure shifts and social network heterogeneity.

title: Mind the scales: Harnessing spatial big data for infectious disease surveillance and inference
summary: This paper analyzes the transformative potential of 'spatial big data' – digital data sources with geographic information – for infectious disease surveillance and inference. It explores how these novel data streams, beyond traditional methods, can enhance public health coordination and disease mitigation, while also addressing the significant technical, practical, and ethical challenges inherent in their application.

title: A generalized-growth model to characterize the early ascending phase of infectious disease outbreaks
summary: This paper introduces a novel 2-parameter generalized-growth model designed to characterize the early ascending phase of infectious disease outbreaks, capturing a spectrum from sub-exponential to exponential growth. By applying this model to 20 diverse outbreaks, the research reveals significant variations in epidemic growth patterns and highlights that sub-exponential growth is a common and crucial phenomenon for accurate disease forecasting.

title: Molecular Infectious Disease Epidemiology: Survival Analysis and Algorithms Linking Phylogenies to Transmission Trees
summary: This paper introduces a robust statistical framework combining survival analysis with novel algorithms to link pathogen phylogenies to transmission trees. It proves a one-to-one correspondence between interior node host assignments and consistent transmission trees, enabling more efficient and generalizable estimation of disease transmission parameters. Validated by simulation and applied to a Foot-and-Mouth Disease Virus outbreak, this method offers a rigorous foundation for molecular infectious disease epidemiology, emphasizing the importance of data from uninfected individuals.

title: Introduction to statistical inference for infectious diseases
summary: This paper serves as an introduction to statistical inference for infectious diseases, beginning with the general stochastic epidemic model. It comprehensively outlines methods for estimating crucial model parameters like the basic reproduction number ($R_0$) and vaccination coverage ($v_c$) from various data types, including final outbreak details, temporal data, or ongoing outbreak observations, while considering individual and mixing heterogeneities. Additionally, it surveys statistical techniques for parameter estimation and addresses the critical issue of early outbreak detection in infectious disease surveillance.

title: Indirect transmission and the effect of seasonal pathogen inactivation on infectious disease periodicity
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model describing the indirect transmission of infectious diseases via an environmental pathogen reservoir, focusing on how seasonal environmental conditions influence disease periodicity. A key finding is the identification of a time delay between peak pathogen survival and peak disease incidence, driven by a seasonally forced pathogen inactivation rate, with the period of disease oscillations matching that of the environmental forcing.

title: Spatial dynamics of airborne infectious diseases
summary: This paper presents an epidemiological model to investigate the spatial dynamics of airborne infectious disease transmission in indoor environments, focusing on the roles of pathogen-carrying droplets and ambient airflow. It reveals that larger droplets (~4 μm) are significant vectors for disease propagation, while smaller droplets (~0.4 μm) pose a negligible risk. Crucially, the research identifies a threshold air velocity that can impair disease transmission, even when the basic reproduction number ($R_0$) is above unity, highlighting the effectiveness of ventilation as an infection control measure.

title: Modelling the strategies for age specific vaccination scheduling during influenza pandemic outbreaks
summary: This paper utilizes an age-structured compartmental model to evaluate the impact of age-specific vaccination scheduling during an influenza pandemic outbreak, comparing five strategies. It finds that age-specific scheduling significantly reduces attack rates, with the best strategy achieving up to a 10% reduction compared to others, and critically emphasizes the importance of early vaccination campaign initiation. The study also highlights the necessity of considering immunity development delay for accurate impact assessment.

title: The Impact of Past Epidemics on Future Disease Dynamics
summary: This paper develops two mathematical approaches, grounded in percolation theory, to model consecutive seasonal outbreaks of partially-immunizing infections within populations characterized by heterogeneous contact networks. It reveals how immunity acquired from past epidemics fundamentally restructures the epidemiologically active host population, thereby limiting the potential of subsequent outbreaks, and speculates that this dynamic could drive the evolution of increased pathogen infectiousness.

title: Profiling of a network behind an infectious disease outbreak
summary: This paper introduces a novel method to solve an inverse problem, identifying the effectively decisive network topology and transmission parameters governing stochastic infectious disease spread. It leverages early growth phase outbreak data by integrating stochastic differential equations with epidemiological compartment and meta-population network models, using maximal likelihood estimation for inference. The method was validated with both synthetic and real-world SARS outbreak data.
